docs.title: About me
docs.text: Hello! I am Ephron Twagirimana. I am a Software Developer and IoT Specialist based in Rwanda, passionate about using technology to solve community issues. With a background in both technical education and software engineering, I bridge the gap between complex embedded systems and real-world applications.

docs.title: About Me
docs.text:
Quick Bio

  • Location: Kigali, Rwanda
  • Current Role: Software Developer
  • Education: MSc in IoT Embedded Computing Systems (ACEIoT)

docs.title: My Journey
docs.text:
Born in 1996 in Muhanga, I have always been driven by technical innovation. After completing my Bachelor's degree at the University of Rwanda, College of Science and Technology (School of ICT) in 2023, I dedicated a year to shaping the next generation as a Network and Internet Technology Teacher in secondary education.

In late 2023, I transitioned fully into the tech industry as a Software Developer, where I combine my innovative approach with strong technical skills to drive results.

docs.title: Student Introduction
docs.text: I am Ephron Twagirimana, a Master of Science student in IoT Embedded Computing Systems (ECS). This portfolio documents my journey in Modeling & Fabrication.

docs.title: Course Understanding
docs.text:
This documentation explores the core philosophy that design and making are inseparable.

In this module, we move beyond simple manufacturing to understand that design today is computational, material-driven, and production-aware.

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
The Design-to-Fabrication Continuum

The process is not a straight line. It is an iterative cycle:

  1. Design: Establishing intent.
  2. Model: Representing form, logic, and behavior.
  3. Prototype: Testing assumptions.
  4. Fabricate: Transforming models into physical artifacts.
  5. Evaluate: Using feedback to improve the design.

docs.title: Modeling Workflow
docs.text:
Modeling is more than just creating a shape; it is the representation of form, logic, and behavior. My workflow incorporates two distinct approaches:

  1. Geometric Modeling: Defining static shapes and physical dimensions.
  2. Parametric & Rule-Based Modeling: Using parameters to enable variation without needing to redesign the entire object.

docs.title: Design Decisions
docs.text: Every design choice was made with the understanding that fabrication method is a design choice.

docs.title: Parametric Thinking
docs.text:
By utilizing parametric thinking, I treat my models as research tools. This allows me to: * Test assumptions about fit and function. * Quickly adjust variables when physical constraints change.

A parametric model.

docs.title: Fabrication Paradigms
docs.text:
To transform my digital models into physical reality, I considered the four main paradigms of digital fabrication[cite: 44]:

Additive: Layer-by-layer construction e.g., 3D Printing. Subtractive: Removing material e.g., CNC Milling Formative: Shaping via molds and forces. Hybrid: Combining methods for optimal results.

docs.title: Material & Tolerance Considerations
docs.text: Real-world fabrication introduces physical constraints that digital models often ignore.

docs.title: The Iterative Process
docs.text: The most important lesson from this module is that the process is iterative, not linear. Feedback was gathered at every stage, allowing me to refine the design before final production.

docs.title: Failures as Learning
docs.text: I treated every prototyping failure not as a mistake, but as a learning tool. This "evidence in design inquiry" helped me understand the limitations of my chosen machines.

docs.title: Ethics & Sustainability
docs.text: Beyond the technical skills, I reflected on the ethical implications of my work: Sustainability: considering material waste and energy use. Responsibility: Designing for reuse and repair rather than disposability.

docs.title: Final Learning Outcomes
docs.text: Through this project, I have learned to: 1. Design with fabrication logic in mind. 2. Understand material behavior and its impact on form. 3. Translate ideas into buildable, functional systems.
